Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2010 09:15PM AnnetteS wrote: Good question.  I believe that if they take out three and one is positive, but the other two are clear, they stop there.  However, I had an enlarged node (4cm) that was biopsied and found to be cancerous before my surgery. So, my doc said she was taking out all of them on that side.  It was the only one with any cancer.... I'm not sure why they all had to come out.........
Posts.Title: don't get the whole "nodes" protocol slcst12 otter

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2011 01:00AM AnnetteS wrote: I had cellulitis on my breast and side right as I was supposed to have my exchange surgery.  After trying a couple oral antibiotics, I had an IV for ten days.  I am not sure at the moment what was in the IV, but it seemed to work.  We put the medicing in at night and I went about my normal routine with the iv thingie taped to my hand through out the day.  The IV antibiotics seemed to work for me.  My fever went down and my breast was no longer hot, although it did remain red for months.  Now it is still a little pinker than the other side. Good luck to you!
Posts.Title: Looks like Lymphedma - Can It Be Cancer Recurrence? hope1 beacher4209

Posts.Content: AnnetteS wrote: I have (prior to surgery) stage I in my left and stage II in my right.  I have heard statistics for getting a second case of bc.  But I haven't heard anything about getting a third case.  I most people only get two, then I should be good now, right? This is what I kept thinking while trying to decide which surgery to opt for.  Both are small carcinomas in large breasts so I am a candidate for two lumpectomies.   I know it is a personal decision, but anyone want to share what they did and why? Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2011 06:46AM AnnetteS wrote: I need a thesaurus or dictionary if I am going to continue to read this thread I have had numerous blood pressures (all with the hand pumped thingie, not the automatic one), about 10 IVs and a million blood draws (that was a hyperbole) on my at risk arm and so far, I am okay.  Each and every time I am scared to death, but the people I have been dealing with refuse to use my foot or leg or anywhere else (I've tried and tried and gave up).  I usually refuse bp when I go to the doctor (get about one a month just in case).   I am heading for an MRI tomorrow and I don't recall that they do the blood pressure but I do know that is another IV.  I'm hoping this one will use my foot, since it is at a hostpital. (I already have LE in one arm and am at risk in the other)... OKay, I'm off to find a dictionary now.
Posts.Title: What are negative effects of taking BP on lymphedema arm? MrJoseph serenitywisdom

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2011 07:05PM AnnetteS wrote: There is a thread somewhere on this site that has many clever comebacks for when people ask about le sleeves.  My daughter keeps insisting that when someone asks me about mine, that I reply, "oh, it is to cover up my FU tattoo." I am guessing I would never have the nerve to do that, but it probably would shut them up pretty quickly. I was planning on going shopping for a new swim suit after I got my new soft and squishy boobs a few weeks ago.  However, due to infection, I was unable to have the surgery so I will have my expanders for the summer.  I had not thought about how a swimsuit would affect my le. Ugh, another thing to worry about.   I also work in a school and the kids are great and never say anything. However, today I did get a couple of gasps from them.  I am not currently wearing a sleeve because I think it makes my le worse.  I have red welts at the wrist and upper arm when I wear it.  (I think I need one that fits properl) Anyway, I was holding my teachers edition of a book longer than I usually do.  When I put it down, there was a DEEP indentation in my arm. I glanced at it and heard a few gasps from the students, but no one said anything.   I just smiled and said, "I guess I shouldn't hold my book like that any more. Don't worry, it will go away :-)"
Posts.Title: So sick of this. Suzybelle cookiegal

Posts.Content: AnnetteS wrote: I'm a little anxious about this summer.  We have  trips planned to places where it is quite hot, (Nevada, Arizona and Tennessee) and where there will be water in the form of lakes, rivers and pools.  I know that swimming is great and I don't need compression.  I am afraid the hot weather (and maybe the humidity in Tenn?) might aggrevate my LE so I feel I need compression out of the water.  We tend to go in and out of the water quite often.  I cannot imagine trying to get my sleeve on and off through out the day, especially when I am hot and sweaty.   Should I wear my sleeve in the water? Or not wear a sleeve out of the water? I am not wanting to go to these miserably hot locations and not be able to go in the water...... I just realized that at the lake, I have to use my arms to pull myself out of the water and onto the boat.  I am pretty sure I should have my sleeve on for this. Is it okay to wear the sleeve in the water?   I should have posted this in the grrrr I hate LE thread because that is exactly how I am feeling right now. Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2011 07:46PM AnnetteS wrote: I am sorry you are having to deal with the stress of losing something so important to you. I started losing my hair in large quantities on day 14.  We had a good time cutting and shaving it into a mohawk and taking some silly pictures. Then proceeded to finish it off.  We didn't shave it smooth, but about 1/8 inch or so.  I lost almost all of my hair, but there were twenty or so short hairs left in each square inch of my scalp.  I am not like most ladies, as I was concerned that I had not lost all my hair.  I complained to my onc. because I was worried that if the chemo (TC x6) was not killing ALL my hair, how could I be sure it was killing ALL my cancer. I actually still wonder about this, even though I've been told not to worry about it. But, the good news for you is that it WILL grow back.  And, you might even like the new hair even better. Like others have mentioned, having no or short hair is REALLY easy.  Mine is now about an inch long and I am pretty sure I will be keep it short.  I love how easy it is.
Posts.Title: Million Dollar Question on Hair Loss! Rockym nicholewilliams

Posts.Content: AnnetteS wrote: I have read several places and was told by a therapist that the manual lymphatic drainage massage should be very light on the skin.  I have heard "like petting a kitty" or "just enough to move the skin" or " like brushing something off" I am in the process of my therapy where they teach me how to wrap, skin care, etc.  My first therapist stroked my skin very softly.  The second one did more like a massage. Not DEEP muscle massage, but definately a LOT harder than I expected.  I asked her why the difference and she said that the two therapists went to different schools and learned different techniques.  She said that her way (the harder one) was a newer method. She knew exactly how the first one did it. I saw huge improvements in my arm after the first treatment (with the light touch) and no improvement after three of the harder treatments.  I am not sure if it is because you would expect more improvement in the beginning or if this new girl isn;t going it right. Also. when I take off my bandages, I have areas where the swelling is down, but then it goes right back up after a half hour or so. I'm I missing something? Is it okay for it to be either soft or hard?  I will have a third therapist for my last three sessions, but I have no idea how she will do it. I got one drain out,  and the other two still have 60ish ccs per day.  Also, I have dead skin on the underside of one breast but she said if she took it out, it would expose my expander, so it is just sitting there, slowly falling off onto the guaze I put in my  ra.  Anyone else have these experiences?

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2010 05:08AM AnnetteS wrote: Thanks, JanetinVirginia Myrrl, I am not sure of the exact size of the areas they were concerned about, but they were each a little smaller than the palm of my hand. Basically it was the entire underside of each 'breast; I spent 12 hours in the hyperbaric chamber (2 hours a day) and now the only area that did not respond to the oxygen is a little bigger than a quarter. PS says that if she removes the dead tissue, she will reach the tissue expander.  She said that the living tissue around the dead tissue might work its way through and around and under and over the dead tissue and we will be okay.  Does that even make any sense to anyone? You said you felt better getting rid of the dead tissue.  I think that sounds like a good idea..... Right now I am wishing I had opted to just stay flat.  It would be the only flat part of my body.  I hate the TE.

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2010 05:59PM AnnetteS wrote: I got another drain out yesterday and the ps said that the last one is coming out next week no matter what.  It is still draining about 60 cc a day.  Hopefully it will stop draining so much.  I asked what happens to the fluid when she takes it out and she said it will accumulate in my chest and she will have to remove it.  So, I'm not sure which is worse, a drain or her removing fluid later.  Has anyone else had their drain taken out while it was still draiing quite a bit? On another note, my DH planned a recovery party for me in Havasu the first weekend of December with a pretty big PARTY group.  He was quite relieved to hear that my chemo won't start until the week after the party, so I should be able to attend this 'recovery' party.   I don't really have an interest in going to a party with every one drinking while I am still in the middle of recovering, but he is so excited, that I am trying to not sound too negative about it.  I am also having trouble deciding if I want to go back to work during chemo.  I pay for salary protection insurance, so I will still get paid after my sick days run out, Oncologist said the worst side effect (besides the hair loss, which isnt that important to me) is fatigue.  He said you must rest when you get tired.  I teach 30 nine year olds.  They are a great class, and I can certainly sit in my chair and do lessons from the computer,  but there isn't really an option to go to the break room and rest if I get tired.

Posts.Title: diabetic/pricking finger Halah Halah

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2010 09:28AM AnnetteS wrote: Day seven out and I have quit taking valium and vicodin together. I feel like I have completely lost this past week.  My daughter started keeping a journal of funny things I do or say. According to my caretaker, yesterday I had a whiny day.  Well, I made sure that didn't happen today.  I don't believe I whined one time.  However, I have cried about a thousand times today.  I cannot seem to stop it. period. I just keep crying. I got my path report today.  Pretty much as expected.  Left breast had 1 cm IDC that I knew about and another 1 cm IDC that was suspected. but I was suprised about the TWO 4 cm DCISs in the left breast. 0 of 2 nodes were positive :-) adn all the margins were clear. On  the right breast, the IDC was 2 cm (which is twice the size we expected), had a 2 cmDCIS. 21 of the 22 nodes were clean :-).  We already knew one node had cancer, but was suprised that it was 4 cm! I had been told that chemo was a must since I had a lymph node involved.  Now BS is saying she isn't sure.  I am making arrangements to have at least 2 but probably 3 onc opinions.   Also... I know that most people have trouble sleeping and need a wedge or a recliner.  It does not matter what I do, unless I am sitting straight up, I cannot get my lower back to stop hurting (I did not have ny surgery down there)  At first I thought it was just from being in the hospital bed for three nights, but it won't go away....
Posts.Title: October 2010 Mastectomy cc4npg cc4npg

I have to keep gauze on it because it is leaves black stains on whatever it touches.  My PS does not want to clean it out because it will reach the TE.  She says it will heal itself.  Do you think that the fact that it is 'wet' is a good sign that it is not completely dead or maybe it is healing?

I did have two nodes from one side and 22 taken from the other side... not sure if that should make a difference. Boatergrl, Costa Mesa's good.  I get so sad as I drive by so many closed businesses, but I'm sure that is happening everywhere.  Where abouts did your brother live? I'm off Fair Drive.  Wouldn't it be funny if we knew some of the same people.

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2010 05:05AM AnnetteS wrote: My BS told me NO lifting arms above shoulders for four weeks.  She stressed that a number of times.  Maybe because of the ancilliary node disection?
Posts.Title: October 2010 Mastectomy cc4npg cc4npg

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2010 03:26AM AnnetteS wrote: Oh my, I remember the first time I tried to flush the toilet.  I didn't have to in my hospital room because they were measuring my output. But when I went down to the oxygen chamber and went potty, I tried and tried to flush and couldn't.  I even started to try to use my foot to flush, but go scared I would fall.  I finally decided that if the nurse could take my surgical bra on and off, she could flush the toilet for me..... I did not know about only healing when asleep.  That is good to know.  No more feeling guilty for those many naps a day. :-)

Posts.Title: October 2010 Mastectomy cc4npg cc4npg

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2011 04:05PM AnnetteS wrote: Thanks for all the input, everyone. I asked about a port before I began chemo and my med onc said it was up to his nurses, if they could find a vein, we wouldn't need a port. For my second tx, one nurse (if she even is a nurse) needed the  help of the other nurse (who later told me she is a medical assistant) After the assistant got it in, the first gal asked her why  it was so hard to get in.  Was there a valve in the way? When I told them it was really hurting my wrist and arm, she said that it is in the vein.  If it wasn't in the vein, then my hand would be swelling up. Then they said it probably hurt because the meds just came out of the fridge.  I took percocet and started feeling better after a bit.  I'm not sure if it would have kept hurting or not.... I complained a week later to the onc that my arm was swollen and red and hurt and he put me on antibiotics.  He said, "I don't think it is infected but we will try the antibiotics" He also said "It isn't that the iv went into the tissues, or it would have swelled up immediately." While having a debridement (sp?) surgery, I asked the anesthesiologist if she didn't think I should have a port.  She agreed and then stopped short and said, "Wait, you are here because you are not healing.  You probably shouldn't get a port." Anyway, PS is in surgery all day, Onc is on vacation, BS will see me on Tuesday and maybe get me a referal for LE specialist then. And, PCP won't give me one without me coming in next week. So, I struck out for today, but maybe next week I can get a referal. I am completely dreading chemo 3 on Thursday.  I just don't see how my hand/arm can handle one more. I guess I should get in to onc on Monday and complain AGAIN about my hand and arm.  Oh and, I'm diabetic, so a foot IV probably isn't recommended.  I've never heard of a neck IV.  Maybe that is what I should have...... Thanks again for all the input.  I will keep you updated.
Posts.Title: LE with only two nodes out? AnnetteS Jainey

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2011 09:39PM AnnetteS wrote: Are there people getting chemo who do not benefit from it?  I did not read the link that was with that question, but I have an answer I got from my oncologist.  He said that about 50% of the people in MY situation of having one positive node will benefit from the chemo and the other 50% do not need the chemo.  He went on to say that since we have NO idea who belongs to which group, they give the chemo to 100% of the patients in my situation (unless the patient refuses it, I'm guessing).  So, did I need the chemo?  I have no idea.  Did it kick my ass?  It did.  Am I glad I did it? Yes.   One thing that I was worried about, and still enters my mind occassionally is.....If the chemo is supposed to kill the fast growing cells, and it only killed 95% of my hair, did it only kill 95% of any remaining cancer cells? I would have felt better if 100%  of my hair fell out!
Posts.Title: Chemo and Breast Cancer - Another Perspective PlantLover LtotheK

Posts.Content: AnnetteS wrote: I've had two chemo infusions, six blood draws and quite a few blood pressure readings on my left arm, since that side only had two nodes taken out.  (the right side had 22 taken out) My left arm is swollen on the top of my hand where it is also red and burns from the chemo infusions.  My wrist is swollen as is the upper arm.  My PS and oncologist both said it wouldn't be LE because I only had two lymph nodes taken out.   Both times I had chemo, my arm hurt for the entire infusion. My oncologist said that it shouldn't hurt.  But it DOES hurt.  Tomorrow I will be calling PS BS oncologist and PCP to see if I can get a referal to LE Specialist. Any suggestions on what I should say when they tell me again, that since I only had two nodes taken out, LE isn't an issue. I understand that this might not be LE, but there is definately something wrong with my arm and Onc and PS have no idea what is wrong with it.  Just that it isn't LE. Bilateral breast cancer diagnoses within a week of each other. Dx 9/20/2010, IDC, 4cm, Stage II, Grade 2, 1/24 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: LE with only two nodes out? AnnetteS Jainey
